https://t.co/fXwVZEAqI9

"I am so passionate about my future career working for the NHS and hope to go on to secure a role on the wards to help children from my community. I'm from Coventry and the dream is @nhsuhcw or @Bham_Childrens."

"I am so fortunate to be on my university course with the support from my lecturers and my peers. I am super excited for the year ahead and wearing my ‚Äúblues‚Äù with pride, I'm also looking forward to another year with my friends and getting qualified."

"I have come across so many different cases and developed confidence in myself and what I love, and created the most amazing bonds with the children, families and staff that I have had the pleasure of working alongside."

Liv says: "During my two years on this course, I have learned so many new skills that have allowed me to excel while on placement and as a nurse. I have so far completed four placements and have loved every one of them."

Liv was inspired to become a nurse after her experience of NHS care as a child, but thought her dreams were dashed until a foundation course at @covcampus gave her the chance to re-apply through clearing. 

Now, two years later, Liv's on her way to being a registered nurse. üßµ https://t.co/YhZsz013TI

During a difficult few years, people from all walks of life have taken the time to volunteer and make a difference to patients and staff ‚Äì just as they do every year.

Volunteers are supported by staff mentors and are offered job shadowing opportunities to support their applications for paid roles. Within just a few months the trust had exceeded its target by recruiting around 100 new volunteers and providing opportunities within 23 wards.

Using a small grant from @NHSEngland the trust is helping disadvantaged people into employment through an ambitious volunteer-to-career strategy. Volunteers become Response Ward Helpers carrying out non-clinical tasks which improve patient experience and save staff time.

‚ÄúWe wanted to widen participation and use volunteering as an employment entry point for our communities which have suffered the most from the pandemic.‚Äù 

Stevie Cheesman, Project Lead @CHFTNHS shares how hospital #volunteering provides a vital first step into NHS careers. https://t.co/oeHDLl3VSW

RT @RoyalDevonNHS: It‚Äôs International Day of the Midwife. Thank you to our midwives and maternity support workers and everyone else who wor‚Ä¶

‚ÄúI owe a debt of gratitude to my family who have been very supportive and have been understanding with me coming home late and having a long day at work. I can safely say I trained at East and North Herts, but I have been nurtured at West Herts.‚Äù

‚ÄúI have had many opportunities for further studies, including MSc, complex pregnancies, clinical mentorship, and postgraduate studies to mention a few, all of which has helped me in current role as diabetes lead midwife.
‚ÄúThis included working closely with our doctors, and listening and learning about the care of our women and their families.

‚ÄúAfter my initial rotation within maternity, I then settled on the labour ward where I eventually become one of the labour ward coordinators. This role broadened my scope of learning and helped me to further understand the midwifery profession.

‚ÄúI started my midwifery career at West Herts NHS Trust, where I was supported and mentored by the then senior midwives most of whom have retired now. They were incredibly experienced, and tutoring us junior midwives was something they took pride in.

‚ÄúI qualified as staff nurse from University of Hertfordshire in 2001. For the first three years I worked as a staff nurse at the Lister Hospital Stevenage. I then returned to the University of Hertfordshire to study for BSc Hons in midwifery.

‚ÄúI've met so many incredible people, from the families we care for, to our students and domestic staff. I feel very proud to be a midwife - to all my mentors I say thanks for believing in me.‚Äù Diabetes lead midwife Angelina @WestHertsNHS has worked in the NHS 21 years #IDM2022 üëá https://t.co/TxHUgUVc6T
